story: Exclusive: Tory MPs £, link to China spy firm as he gets £, for four extra jobsThe cash for extra jobs scandal grows as it emerges wealthy backbencher Richard Fuller MP has four roles outside Parliament and advised a company that invests in surveillance kit, with Labour expressing human rights fears on the spy techConservative MP Richard Fuller has four other jobs Image: Richard Townshend PhotographyByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations Editor:,  Nov | commentsA Tory MP has received over £, from extra work – with a huge chunk coming from a firm which invests in spy technology in China.Richard Fuller is an advisory director for Investcorp – one of FOUR jobs on top of being an MP.The private equity firm has paid him more than £, while he has been an MP. Investcorp helped bankroll a firm which worked for the Chinese government on surveillance systems capable of tracking oppressed Uyghur Muslims. It is feared a million Uyghurs are held in “brainwashing” detention camps, that women have been sterilised and children taken away.  Articial intelligencecompany Sense Time said its technology could identy Uyghurs by facial recognition. Yet Mr Fuller, , sat on a parliamentary committee which examined treatment of the Uyghur people in Xinjiang – and recommended fines for UK firms using supply chains linked to the province.Mr Fuller – educated at Oxford and Hard – is MP for North East Bedfordshire. His earnings are within the rules, but the new details come as the Tories are mired in sleaze over extra income and Boris Johnson is under pressure to ban secondary jobs for his MPs. Last night Labour ’s deputy leader Angela Rayner said: “The corruption scandal that has engulfed the Conservative Party gets worse by the day.“We need an investigation to get to the bottom of whether this relationship has put our national ­security at risk and whether this technology has aided human rights abuses in China.”  MPs are paid £,. Mr Fuller’s additional income is extensive. In  he quit a post with software company Impero Solutions with a £, payoff. But he continued as an advisory director at £, a year for just two hours work a month. He also makes £, a year from OpSec Security and £, from software company Enviivo. He has worked for Investcorp on and off since . From - the register of MPs’ financial interests shows he received £,. He lost the Bedford seat in  but was elected in North East Beds two years later. Since then he has had £, – seven quarterly sums of £, plus £,, £, and £, for extra work. Hazem Ben-Gacem, co-CEO of global firm Investcorp, has given Mr Fuller £, in political donations since . Investcorp has pumped millions into technology firms in China.  In , it invested in the China Everbright Limited New Economy Fund. In  it started to jointly manage the fund, overseen by the Chinese government. A key beneficiary was Sense Time, which has done work for China’s powerful propaganda unit. In a  patent for a facial-recognition product, Sense Time stated: “It is possible to ide the ethnicities... according to Han, non-Han and unknown, or according to Han, Uyghur, non-Han, non-Uyghur, and unknown.” Investcorp also backed Terminus, an AI firm involved in fitting “surveillance cam-eras with image identication capability” in some Chinese cities. Last night a spokesman for Sense Time said its patent was “never designed” to “discriminate against any groups” and said it liaised with the UN and other international organisations. He added: “Such an action is a violation of our company values. The patent application was amended. We are committed to promoting the responsible and sustainable use of AI.” Alkan Akad, of Amnesty International, said: “There are grave human rights violations in China. Some include the use of extreme surveillance and articial intelligence. from around the world.Ayse, who is from Lancaster, chatted to Kenda, , on the group. Kenda, from Michigan in the US, mentioned her son Darrin was a similar age to Ayse and that he wanted to chat to someone across the pond. “It’s funny that I met my mother-in-law before I met my husband,” Ayse said. “We got on so well, so when she suggested speaking to her son, I thought it was a great idea – although I was a bit nervous at first because I’d seen photos of him and he looked lovely.” When she was first put in touch with Darrin, the pair spoke frequently as friends - but it wasnapost long before their relationship developed into something more. “I told him about my hobbies, how old I was, where I was from, that sort of thing,” Ayse said. “I knew he was from the US so didn’t expect anything from it but thought it would still be interesting to chat to someone from somewhere .” Within weeks, they were calling each other every single night - despite the five hour time dference, meaning Ayse was often falling asleep at am UK time. After they made their relationship official in November , Ayse started planning her trip to the US to meet her beau in the flesh for the first time. But the meet-up in July was put on hold by strict travel restrictions to the States. When she tried to fly to Michigan indirectly via Mexico, her plans were scuppered when she arrived in the US as she was turned away by immigration. “I think they thought thatthey let me into the US then I’d never leave because of Darrin,” Ayse said. It was so heart-breaking to be so close to him in the same city, but not be allowed through the border. I was put on the next flight home and cried the whole way back.  The pair managed as best as they could by having weekly aposdate nightsapos on video calls - ordering each other takeaway food and treats to their door. On  May , Darrin popped the question - and Ayse said yes. “When he answered the call he seemed so nervous which was unlike him – but I soon understood why when he got down on one knee and asked me to marry him,” she recalled. The couple knew it would be a while before they could meet in person, so they decided not to waste any time and tie the knot as soon as they could - over Zoom. On th August, the pair officially became husband and we over a video call ceremony officiated in the US state of Utah.  Joining them on the call were a few of their most cherished family and friends, who watched the pair say their vows. The married couple, who still havenapost met face to face, speak several times every day, hoping Ayseaposs visa application will soon be accepted so they can enjoy le together as husband and we. Ayse, a cleaner, from Lancaster, Lancs, said: “I never imagined this would happen to me in a million years. “I don’t think anyone expected this when we started talking last year. “But we’re married and it’s all completely legal and official – I still can’t believe it. “It’s been really hard not being able to meet properly, but in the long run it will make us stronger because we’ve had to go through all of this to be together. We just really love each other.” Looking back on their whirlwind relationship, Ayse is grateful both their families are supportive of their union. “I didn’t tell my parents straight away when we first started talking, but they twigged there was something going on when I was on the phone all the time,” Ayse said.  “They had reservations about it to start with – but I suggested they chat to Darrin on Skype and they saw straight away how crazy we both are about each other. As we haven’t met in person yet we haven’t been able to have a physical relationship, which means that our marriage is based off of more than that, he said. story: Bigfoot hunter claims giant footprint and claw marks are ‘proof’ beast is in UK woodlandLee Brickley, , says he found tracks and claw marks after a decade searching for the ape-like beast and the print was cm from toe to heel – nearly twice the size of a man’s size eight footLee Brickley Image: Mercury Press  Media Ltd.ByAntony Leena AshkenazWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments An investigator claims to have found proof of the elusive British Bigfoot.Lee Brickley says he found tracks and claw marks after a decade searching for the ape-like beast. The -year-old says the print was a terrying cm from toe to heel – nearly twice the size of a man’s size eight. Lee knows people will think he is “mad” but he hopes to prove them wrong. He said: “When I show them the pictures they’re amazed.There have been sightings of a yeti-like creature around Cannock Chase in Staffordshire dating back to the s, Daily Star reports.Lee has heard of  in the past two years and has even camped in the woods in a bid to spot the creature that’s known in the US as Sasquatch.  He said: “Loads of people now message me regularly asking for updates. I got an anonymous email from a man saying he had been flying a remote control plane over Gentleshaw Common at Cannock Chase who said he’d seen something unusual. With his description of the location, I went out there straight away, and found the footprint. “I was astounded… I’d never seen a footprint that large in my le, and it was clearly not made using a mould or cast “That is probably the moment I realised the Cannock Chase Bigfoot was more than just a myth.” A month later, Lee found the claw marks on a tree near a mutilated deer. He said: “It looked as though something had bitten and then ripped out its throat before eating from the torso.  “You see a lot of dead deer on Cannock Chase – often they’ve been hit by cars – but it was unusual to see one in that condition.” Lee claims he caught a glimpse of Bigfoot once while researching for his book. He said: “I can’t say for sure what it was, as it was around  pm and getting dark and the figure was covered in shadow. “It definitely moved more like an animal than a man, and it was easily seven feet tall. “I tried to run after it, but it was too quick and disappeared into a dense section of trees.” Lee has been fascinated with Bigfoot ever since he was a child.  He said: “I remember watching Bigfoot documentaries with my dad when I was young. “All the famous sightings were in America, so when I was a bit older I started researching any UK sightings I could find. “I just kept going from there and here I am.” Lee has published multiple books on supernatural occurrences in Cannock Chase, including his most recent book on Bigfoot. Lee said: “There have actually been many sightings since as far back as the s of man-monkey type creatures in Staffordshire. “Reports of these sightings seem to have drastically increased in number and frequency since the beginning of . “I think people like to keep an open mind about these things. “Especially after they have read the reports and seen the evidence for themselves.” Comment MORE ON Bigfoot" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Deep-sea exotic fish mysteriously washes up on British coast in bizarre discoveryThe goldfish-like boar fish is the latest in a series of findings after three fish were reported in three locations over a three-week period during March and April this yearThe bizarre goldfish-like Boar Fish was spotted floating along a beach in Devon Image: Ziggy Austin   SWNSByEd CullinaneGraeme Murray:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA deep-sea exotic fish has been found washed up on the British coast in the latest of a series of bizarre findings The goldfish-like boar fish was spotted floating along a beach in Devon by a family walking their dogs. Youngsters Ellie, , and Lauren, , pointed out the strange fish to their sea-obsessed father Ziggy Austin on Maidencombe beach in Torquay. This is the latest in a series of findings after three of the fish were reported on the Isles of Scilly, one in Newquay and one in Kimmeridge, Dorset over a three-week period in March and April. Normally no more than two of the fish are recorded to wash up on the coast every year.  The fish, which rarely comes close to the surface from its normally -meter deep habitat, could potentially have been killed by oceanic microplastics - a consequence of water pollution. Subsisting on a diet of worms, prawns and shrimp, the fish consumes creatures well recorded to themselves eat large amounts of microplastics through plankton which then build up in the creature until it dies. Previous studies into sprat and boar fish fish samples have suggested that there is an aposabundanceapos of the tiny plastics ingested by the creatures. Ziggy Austin, , who has run Rock Solid Coasteering in Devon for seven years, said it was a aposrare findapos.He said: It was fresh, it had literally just died, and the weather has been very calm, so it wasnapost pushed here. It must have swum here, but they usually swim in large shoals from the deep ocean.I read online that only two wash up a year, so itaposs pretty rare. I know every single species of fish thataposs out there pretty much, and this was something Iaposd never seen before. So the shoes and socks were straight off and I was straight in there - no hesitation, I had to get my hands on it. It looked like a goldfish with a giant eye. It was only just in the first stage of rigor mortis, so it must have died in the last half an hour. Mum-of-one human, Claire Membury, , bought her first Miniature Dachshund four years ago and became hooked by their inidual and unique personalities. Claire said that the spoilt sausages have a wardrobe bigger than hers, with designer labels such as Gucci, and when theyaposre not cuddling up in the coupleaposs own bed, they relax in two £ orthopaedic beds. The dog groomer, from Shrewsbury, Shropshire, has even moved her bedroom with husband Leigh, , downstairs where they share an ft long bed with the pups.  Claire said: I picked up my first dog about four years ago. Miniature Dachshunds are just incredibly perfect dogs, theyaposre to die for. title: family six say damp home
story: Family of six say damp home like living in shed - and theyre sleeping in loungeJohn Charles and Laura Waddingham told how they had major issues with their home during the autumn and winter months due to a lack of insulation and a bitter draught blowing throughJohn Charles and partner Laura Waddingham Image: Darren Quinton Birmingham LiveByJosh Sandord:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov Parents living in a freezing cold house have begged the council to sort the property out, claiming it is plagued by damp and mould, making their four children unwell. John Charles and Laura Waddingham told how they had major issues with their home during the autumn and winter months due to a lack of insulation and a bitter draught blowing through. The pair said it had left them struggling with their own health and forced to keep their children - aged between eight and  - off school as they had woken up being sick.The family, who moved into the house in April , got in touch with BirminghamLive after claiming to have contacted Birmingham City Council dozens of times and explained they didnapost know what  to do. John and Laura, who live near the border of Birmingham and Solihull, claimed that on one occasion near the start of their tenancy the family had slept in the front room together to try and keep warm. They have since swapped bedrooms so the children are warmer at night - but said their two daughters were still sleeping together for heat rather than on their bunk beds. When we first moved in this house was absolutely freezing, Laura said. We didnapost have any gas the first day we moved in because the appointment had been made for the next day for the gas to be switched on. When the gas was put on, we left the heating on all day and the house was still the same.  It hasnapost warmed up since, itaposs just getting colder in here. Laura, who works as a carer for John who has hearing loss and learning disabilities, said she felt it was affecting them both physically and mentally. I feel lightheaded when Iaposm walking, Laura said. But itaposs only when I walk far that Iaposll get that feeling. And itaposs because of living here. I didnapost have it before. And John said his mental health had taken a hit as he described it as like living in a shed.  When I was sleeping in the bedroom I was suffering that bad I wanted to cry like a baby, he said. I went up and down the stairs to try and sleep downstairs on my own, I couldnapost get to sleep. I didnapost know what to do. The pair said the kids were always complaining they were cold and had been off school because they were ill in the morning. It affects the way they sleep as well, Laura added. They can go to sleep and then they will wake up all of a sudden because theyaposre cold. And family visits and sleepovers are impossible as their living conditions mean they cannot have people around.  John and Laura, who have been together for  years, said they didnapost want to move from the area due to the childrenaposs school but were hoping the council would sort their problems out. They claimed the local authority had attempted to blame them for the damp and mould due to DIY work. Weaposre just hoping that they can sort this problem out because they are the landlord. Laura added. I have been contacting them to help us but they are trying to blame us. John added: Itaposs just a nightmare the way it has changed our lestyles around.  We go out most of the time down to the Wacky [Warehouse] or down to the local pub and have a family dinner because it is affecting us. All we want is for them to sort this house out. I donapost want to move. The school is close and I canapost walk far. I just want them to fix the problem. A Birmingham City Council spokesperson said: Our contractor painted the property in October and on another visit in November tried to carry out repairs and do a damp survey but was not granted access.No damp was picked up when painting the property but clearly with the change in weather there has been damp incursion.We are sorry for the impact that this has had on the tenants. We are working with them to resolve it and will ensure that it is treated as soon as possible. story: Girl, , reunited with teddy lost , miles away at remote Iceland campsiteHattie Sains lost Cowie at a campsite near Vik i Myrdal, Iceland, three months ago, before a chain of kindness saw the stuffed toy make its way home to Billericay, EssexCowie on plane to London after the rescue operation by kind strangers Image: Halldór Ingvason   SWNSByLeigh Mcmanus:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA -year-old Brit was reunited with the cow teddy she left at a remote Icelandic campsite - thanks to a team of strangers who passed it on for , miles using the power of social media. Hattie Sains lost Cowie at a campsite near Vik i Myrdal, Iceland, three months ago and had been distraught ever since.After trying and failing to find a courier tothe ted, her parents Chrissie and Richard Sains,  and , had almost given up before Richard posted on a Facebook group asking for advice and kind strangers offered to get Cowie home.Richard, who said he has always been wary of social media and its dangers, now says that he sees the beauty of it and that he will pay back the kindness his family experienced. Tour guide Óðinn Yngvason, , drove to pick up the toy, and took the toy on a tour of Iceland, snapping pics of the ted at waterfalls, mountains and landmarks.  He handed it over to Facebook well-wisher Halldor Ingvason at Reykjavik airport. Halldor, , was flying to Stanstead for a gig, and picked up a cuddly toy puffin pal, before getting photos of Cowie in the cockpit of the plane. On Thursday, Richard met up with Halldor, from Akureyri, Iceland, in a pub in Bloomsbury where the final handover took place - along with a few pints. Software business owner Richard from Billericay, Essex, said: We were going to keep it a surprise but I kept seeing those photos so I had to show Hattie. She was like aposwhat  Is Cowie going to come home  Please can you make sure heaposs on my bed so when I wake up heaposs there!apos  He added: For me Iaposm always a little bit hesitant with social media - there can be a lot of negativity. But actually you can be put almost immediately in contact with fantastic people around the world who are willing to help you. Iaposm more willing to help people, Iaposll definitely pay it back. Hattie got Cowie when she was just two years old and has been her favourite toy ever since. He accompanied her on her holiday to Iceland with her parents and sister Meg, , in August, for a road trip on the scenic Route One around the country. The night after leaving a campsite near Vik i Myrdal, Hattie couldnapost find Cowie when she was getting into bed. Mum Chrissie said: She was really upset at first. She thought she might have lost him rather than left him. We got in touch with campsite and they said sheaposd left him within the covers of bell tent. Nobody seemed to be able to post him back. They were forced to fly back to the UK without Cowie, but author Chrissie was still determined to get him back. Software business owner Richard decided to give it one last go and post on a Facebook group called aposTravel Icelandapos asking for shipping advice. To his surprise, he received about  comments from kind strangers offering to help shuttle Cowie through dferent legs of his journey. story: Heavily pregnant mum-of-five who died of Covid laid to rest without ever holding newbornThe body of -year-old Saiqa Parveen was taken from her home in Birmingham back to Pakistan where she was laid to rest, her family have revealed. Mrs Parveen caught Covid in SeptemberSaiqa Parveen, who died of Covid leaving her husband Majid Ghafur, and four girls Image: BPM MediaByLeigh Mcmanus:,  Nov | commentsA much-loved mum-of-five who was eight months pregnant when she caught Covid- and never got to hold her newborn daughter has been buried. The body of -year-old Saiqa Parveen was taken from her home in Birmingham back to Pakistan where she was laid to rest, her family have revealed. Mrs Parveen, who caught Covid in September, was put on a ventilator by doctors at Good Hope Hospital, who then delivered her baby, Dua Maryam, at full term.The mother, who had four other daughters, died on November , Birmingham Live reports. The story of her death sparked an outpouring of grief as her brother Qayoum Mughal begged others to get the vaccine.  Funeral prayers were said at a Mosque in Alum Rock and on November , Mr Mughal, her taxi-driver husband Majid Ghafur, , took the sad journey to Siakh, in Mirpur district, where she was laid to rest. Mr Mughal, , said: When Saiqa’s body arrived in her childhood home, the whole of the village was in deep sorrow and grief. “Everyone was shocked. My mother and sisters have been crying and expressing their great loss. “The vast majority of people came from far and wide to attend the funeral and it was one of the biggest gatherings in our village. “The funeral prayer was led by Qazi Mehfooz Ahmed, a prominent member of our community.  “Because my sister passed away at a young age and had no underlying health conditions, people who had doubts about the Covid- vaccine are giving some serious thought about getting it. Earlier this week, maternity leaders say they hope a rise in take-up triggered by publicity about the awful loss will provide some apossmall consolationapos to the family.Janet Driver, Regional Chief Midwe for NHS England and NHS Improvement in the Midlands said: “We are deeply saddened by Saiqa Parveen’s death and send our heartfelt condolences to her family.“I am very grateful that this brave family have stepped forward during their time of grief to support getting the message out to the community and for urging other pregnant women to get the vaccine.  “We know that cases like this do encourage expectant mums to come forward, and hope this is a small consolation to them.” The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists tweeted: “It’s very upsetting to hear about the death of Saiqa Parveen who died from COVID- after her daughter was delivered by emergency caesarean.“Our sympathies go out to her family. news uk-news hero-liverpool-cab-driver-prevented-"Liverpool Women’s Hospital: Police give statement following incidentByLorraine KingNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A hero taxi driver prevented an awful disaster by locking a suspicious passenger in his cab before the vehicle blew up. Quick-thinking David Perry heroically prevented more bloodshed, but was injured himself, following the potential Poppy Day terror attack.His male passenger died after the cab exploded outside Liverpool Womenaposs hospital - Europeaposs largest maternity hospital - on Sunday morning. Mr Perry was standing near the blast which happened seconds before the am minuteaposs Remembrance Day silence was about to begin. He is claimed to have suffered cuts, bruises and damage to his ear drum.Have you been affected by this story  Get in touch at webnews@mirror Mayor of Liverpool Joanne Anderson told BBC Radio aposs Today programme that David had erted a disaster with his heroic action.She said: The taxi driver with his heroic efforts has managed to ert what could’ve been an absolutely awful disaster at the hospital, our thanks go to him. Reports claim Mr Perryaposs male passenger had asked to go to the cityaposs Service of Remembrance before dying in the blast.  Following the explosion anti-terror police carried out several raids across Liverpool and three men - aged , , and  - were detained in the Kensington area of the city and arrested under the Terrorism Act in connection with the incident. A number of locals said armed officers swooped on a terraced house in the afternoon. Dozens of homes have also been evacuated in an operation that is still ongoing on Monday morning.  A source who is close to Mr Perryaposs family told MailOnline that his brave actions has potentially saved lives. They claimed Mr Perry - who has been described as an experienced cab driver - picked up the passenger who initially asked to be dropped off at Liverpoolaposs Anglican Cathedral which is half a mile from the hospital. A Remembrance Sunday parade had just ended and a memorial event featuring thousands of servicemen, veterans and dignitaries was being held at the church.  But the source claimed the route had to be changed due to road closures so the man asked to be dropped off at the centre centre before Mr Perry became suspicious as they drove past the hospital. They said Mr Perry noticed some kind of light attached to his clothing and the man was messing around with it which is when he jumped out of his car and locked the passenger in the back of the vehicle. They said: As soon as he did, itaposs gone off. Davidaposs the luckiest man in Britain as well as the most heroic,this guy got in the hospital God knows what could have happened. Counter-terrorism police said they continue to keep an open mind about the cause of the explosion and are working closely with Merseyside Police. A fundraiser which was set up to support Mr Perry and his family has raised more than £, in just a few hours.  Among those paying tribute to the hero cab driver was Billy Darwin.He posted on Facebook : “David nearly paid the ultimate price to save others apparently not giving anything a second thought besides making sure he went above and beyond to keep the people of Our City safe!”Kev Cuthbertson posted: “He is a hero, when he noticed the bomb, he locked the scumbag in the car. But took the brunt of the blast.”  Stephen Thomas wrote: “The driver is my mate, and spotted the passenger acting suspiciously, so he jumped out the car.” Another, George Cater, wrote: Please send your healing prayers to David Perry, the very brave taxi driver who is in a critical condition in hospital after preventing an attack at am this morning at Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital. David stopped by the women’s hospital and locked the attacker in his cab after noticing the device.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it appears the taxi driver caught up in the Liverpool explosion acted with “incredible presence of mind and bravery”. He also tweeted on Sunday: My thoughts are with all those affected by the awful incident in Liverpool today.I want to thank the emergency services for their quick response and professionalism, and the police for their ongoing work on the investigation.  Earlier, a spokesman for Merseyside Police said: So far we understand that the car involved was a taxi which pulled up at the hospital shortly before the explosion occurred. We are keeping an open mind as to what caused the explosion, but given how it has happened - out of caution - counter terrorism police are leading the investigation supported by Merseyside Police. The Chief Constable of Merseyside Police, Serena Kennedy, has offered her reassurance over the incident.  She said: While I understand that todayaposs incident may cause concern in our communities, it should be pointed out that events of this nature are very rare. Merseyside Police will continue to liaise with community groups, community leaders, partner agencies and iniduals in the coming days and weeks to make sure any concerns are addressed and ensuring that we provide the best possible service to local people.  There will also be an increased and visible police presence on the streets of Merseyside and I would encourage people to engage with my officers and raise any concerns they may have. story: Hero who saved great, great gran, , in Brentford stabbing paid ultimate priceRetired barmaid Betty Walsh, , was said to have been set upon as she went to get her supper at Best Kebab and Fish Bar in Brentford, west LondonAli Abucar Ali was fatally stabbedByGwyn WrightMatthew Young:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A great, great gran could spend a month in hospital after being stabbed in an alleged attempted murder as shocked locals praised the ‘hero’ who saved her. Retired barmaid Betty Walsh, , was said to have been set upon as she went to get her supper at Best Kebab and Fish Bar in Brentford, west London, around pm Friday night. A family friend, -year-old Ali Abucar Ali, who recently won a scholarship to play basketball, was fatally stabbed as he intervened. Betty’s eldest daughter Bridget, , said her mum didn’t realise she had been attacked until Ali stepped in to help. She added: “Ali went up and asked what all the commotion was about, challenged her attacker and tried to help her. What happened to him next was a tragedy. “I knew him and his mother. They are a very good family. His mother had rushed to comfort me as soon as she heard what happened to Mum, before the police phoned her and told her the devastating news that her son had so sadly been stabbed.  “Ali was a really hardworking, good lad who had recently won a scholarship to play basketball.” Bridget said her mum will remain in St Mary’s Hospital in Paddington for a number of weeks after undergoing emergency surgery. She added: ‘’She will come out eventually, but it could be a few weeks or a month.  “We are devastated that we weren’t able to see her yesterday, but my sister has since been allowed to see her.” Her family said the pensioner is no longer on the ‘critical’ list after undergoing a kidney operation following the incident. Mum of six Betty also has  grandchildren,  great grandchildren and a great great granddaughter. A fundraiser set up in memory of Ali’s devastated family had yesterday topped £,. Brentford residents today praised Ali’s bravery in rushing to help Betty.  Laura Williams, , said: ‘’I never knew Ali, but from what I understandhe had not rushed to help poor Betty she probably would have lost her le with immediate effect. “He stopped in a dficult situation and performed a selfless act for which he paid the ultimate price. “I really have no words that can describe how his poor family are feeling. ‘’They deserve every penny raised from the GoFundMe page they have set up. I hope it can form a lasting legacy for him. ‘’They raised a good person who put himself on the line for someone  and tried to come to their rescue. ‘’Brentford has lost a very decent human being. He is a hero,  per cent.’’The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  A man who did not want to be named said: ‘’He is heroic and an inspiration to everyone. “Not many people would do what he did. Betty’s family should be incredibly grateful that he came to her aid.’’ Local Beatrice Kangethe, , said: ‘’He is a hero, but I do not think he expected that to happen. “He thought he would go and help her. What happened is just so sad, the old woman must be traumatised.’’ Deidrie Smith, , said: ‘’He was not thinking of himself when he rushed to help Betty. “He gave his le up but couldn’t have expected something so awful to happen to him.’’ Norris Henry, , from Brentford, was charged today with murder and attempted murder. He will appear at Uxbridge Magistrates’ Court tomorrow. news uk-news kate-middletons-sweet-tribute-princess-"Remembrance Sunday: Royals attend service at CenotaphByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | comments Like most members of the Royal Family, the Duchess of Cambridge paid her respects to the nationaposs war dead at Remembrance events this weekend. On Saturday night she attended the Royal British Legionaposs annual Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall before watching the National Service of Remembrance at the Cenotaph in Central London yesterday morning. And at both events, Kate paid a subtle tribute to her late mother-in-law Princess Diana by wearing some of her jewellery. On Saturday night, she wore Dianaaposs Collingwood pearl earrings that were given to the late princess as a wedding gt in . Kate has sported them several times before, including at the commemorations for the centenary of the Battle of Passchendaele during the First World War in . As well as the earrings, she also wore Dianaaposs three-strand pearl bracelet, which the late princess acquired in . Kate had previously worn the bracelet during a tour of Germany in .Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. And on Sunday, Kate again wore the Collingwood pearl earrings along with an Alexander McQueen coat that had poppies pinned to it. It came as she took centre stage as she watched the Remembrance Sunday service alongside the Duchess of Cornwall and Sophie Wessex.Kate looked solemn as she stood in the middle with Camilla and Sophie at her sides on a balcony of the Foreign Office while Prince Charles, Prince William, Princess Anne and Prince Edward were below as they laid wreaths at the Cenotaph.However, missing from the balcony was the Queen, who had sprained her back and was unable to attend todayaposs Remembrance Sunday service. In previous years, the Queen had stood on the balcony at the centre of Kate and Camilla. Buckingham Palace had said Her Majesty was disappointed to miss the event held annually at the Cenotaph on Whitehall. She was set to lead the nation in commemorating the war dead during her first in-person public engagement since going into hospital. The palace insisted her back strain was not connected to the recent hospital stay where she was forced to spend the night at the King Edward VII in Marylebone last month to undergo “preliminary investigations” for an unknown condition. A royal source said: “It is the most unfortunate timing for Her Majesty who recently had a short break to Sandringham in Norfolk for a few days and was left feeling rested and recuperated on herto Windsor Castle. “On conversation with royal doctors it was decided that a back sprain is not conducive with a car journey and a period of standing. “Her Majesty is deeply disappointed to miss the ceremony.” The Queen had only ever missed six Remembrance Sunday events in her -year reign before yesterday - four due to being abroad on royal tours and two when she was pregnant.Comment MORE ON Remembrance DayKate Middleton, Duchess of CambridgePrincess DianaRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: liverpool poppy day bombing shows
story: Liverpool Poppy Day bombing shows signs of being terror cell and not lone wolfThere are serious signs yesterdays bomb attack outside Liverpools Womens Hospital was the work of an organised terrorist cell, warns former intelligence officer Mike TappFormer intelligence officer Mike Tapp says there are warning signs that the bomb attack on Remembrance Sunday was the work of an organised terror cellopinionByMike Tapp:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov It looks like this cowardly, botched attack has come from a more organised terrorist cell than the “lone wolf” attacks we are more used to seeing. There are many unanswered questions at this stage, but the cell clearly had some bomb-making skills and a radicalised suicide bomber. These factors suggest some expertise that may have been picked up from terrorist activity abroad, possibly with ISIS or even al-Qaeda. Targeting a hospital matches some terrorist tactics used overseas, in Kabul, for example. However, given the timing of this attack, it is more likely that this extremist was seeking to detonate at the nearby Remembrance Day service. Given the speed of arrests, within hours of the attack, it is likely that this cell was known to the police.Extremists ing from terrorist activity abroad are often on police and security service watch lists, but with a lack of evidence available to prosecute them, it is dficult to keep them out of our communities. When more is known, and the police can be sure of no further risk to the public, questions will be asked - such as why was the preparatory activity needed to construct an explosive device not picked up   This would include purchasing components and possibly reconnaissance activity of potential attack locations. This attack demonstrates that the risk from terrorism is very real and goes beyond bedroom radicalised extremists using a kne. My thoughts are very much with the taxi driver and those affected. story: Mum shares birthday with both her children - despite due dates being weeks apartExactly five years later after her first birth Sophie Cheffins second son was also born on her birthday after she went into labour more than two weeks earlier than expected in Southend, EssexNoah on the left, Jacob in the middle and Sophie Cheffins on the right Image: Caters News AgencyByKaty-Rose MeaneyGraeme Murray:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA mum shares her birthday with both of her children - despite their due dates being weeks apart. But exactly five years later - to the day - her second son, Jacob, was again born on her birthday after Sophie went into labour more than two weeks earlier than expected. story: Mum stung by wasp just seconds before fatal crash has charges droppedDog breeder Helen Shaw insisted that she couldnt stop her car veering head-on into Rosina Ingrams Nissan Note due to the pain and shock of the wasp sting to her legHelen Shaw insisted that she couldnt stop her car Image: Ian Cooper   Teesside LiveByKev DonaldJade McElwee:,  Nov | comments A mum-of-three who killed an elderly woman after a wasp sting caused her to lose control of her car has been cleared of blame after a two year ordeal.Helen Shaw insisted that she couldnapost stop her car veering head-on into Rosina Ingramaposs red Nissan Note due to the pain and shock of the sudden sting to her leg. Despite her claims she was charged with causing Mrs Ingramaposs death by careless or inconsiderate driving in the aftermath of the accident in July , Teeside Live reports.The -year-old dog breeder and equestrian worker faced a jail term of up to five yearsshe was convicted by a jury at Teesside Crown Court. The case was due to be heard on Monday but prosecutors announced they wonapost pursue the charge against her. Mrs Shaw, who lives in Yarm, North Yorkshire, a photograph of the sting to her leg as evidence of what happened and the Crown Prosecution Service has now taken her word and dropped the case.`Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter At a previous hearing Mrs Shawaposs barrister Ben Whittingham told the court the wasp sting caused a total absence of voluntary control. She was placed under investigation after the fatal crash involving her grey Seat Leon, an Audi Q and Mrs Ingramaposs vehicle on the A near Kirklevington, Yarm, on July  .Mrs Ingram, , a retired carer from Stockton, had been a passenger in the Nissan and died several days after the accident from chest and abdominal injuries.Two children in the Audi, aged seven and , both suffered minor whiplash, while Mrs Shaw herself suffered a broken foot and whiplash. Mrs Shaw first appeared at Teesside Magistratesapos Court in November, last year, where she denied the offence, sobbing through the short hearing and dabbing her eyes with a tissue.She was told by the chairman of the bench: This is so serious it cannot be heard at the Magistratesapos Court, therefore the trial will be at the Crown Court and your first hearing at the Crown Court will be on the th of January at  oaposclock Until that time you are going to be released on unconditional bail. Mrs Shaw said at that time that she had been hit with more than £, in legal fees and described the surreal experience of finding herself in the dock at a criminal court for the first time.At her home in Yarm she said: I really donapost know why the case had to go to court, I provided evidence straight away that Iaposd been stung by a wasp.There was a picture on my phone and my hospital records which showed Iaposd been given antihistamine for the sting.To find myself in a criminal court facing a potential jail sentence was surreal but very frightening. Of course I looked up the maximum sentence for the crime I was charged with and discovered it was five years in prison.So much goes through your mind. What will happen to me and to my kidsI go to jail  Itaposs been the worst time of my le.I feel very relieved that the case is over, it hasnapost quite sunk in yet.But at the same time there really is no good outcome from this because that other family have lost a whole person from their lives.I canapost say how sorry I am for what happened, itaposs something Iaposll carry around with me for the rest of my le. Mrs Shaw, whose husband works as a welder, was ing home with her daughter and her daughteraposs friend when the accident happened.She said: I was aware of a pain at the back of my leg at the top of my calf and looked down to see a wasp crawling up my leg.It took a matter of seconds but when I looked up the other car was right in front of my and I hit the brakes but couldnapost stop.I broke my ankle in what Iaposve been told is a typical injury from braking. It was devastating to be told the lady in the other car had died.It affected me very badly and I lived with that for over a year until in October last year the police rang me and said they had investigated and were about to bring charges. She continued: It came so out of the blue that I couldnapost comprehend it at first. I must have cried for weeks, it was horrendous.Attending a criminal court for the first time was awful, sitting in the dock with my bag, feeling like a criminal.It cost thousands in legal fees because I didnapost apply for Legal Aid, assuming I wouldnapost qualy.My dad, who worked hard all his le at ICI, paid my legal fees and it came to more than £,. Iaposm so grateful to him for that but it should never have been necessary.I have no idea how a case can be taken through the courts for a year before the Crown Prosecution Service decides thereaposs no case to answer.They had the evidence from the start. I was stung by a wasp and the accident happened because of that, but my family and I have still been through all of this. My main thought is still with the family of the lady who died. They must have been angry and must have had questions but I hope they donapost hate me too much.Comment MORE ON Ian CooperHospitalsCourt caseCrown courtLegal aidCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum thanks fantastic paramedics response
story: Mum thanks fantastic paramedics for response after daughter, , stops breathingCharlotte Phillips, , said the ambulance and "fantastic" paramedics got to her three-year-old daughter, Amelia, within three minutes of the call to  on Tuesday  NovemberCharlotte Phillips said the paramedics helped the family come back around from a traumatic experienceByZhara SimpsonLeigh Mcmanus:,  Nov | commentsA young mum wants to thank two fantastic paramedics for their quick and efficient response after her three-year-old daughter went into an anaphylactic shock and stopped breathing. Charlotte Phillips said the ambulance and paramedics got to her daughter, Amelia, within three minutes of the call to  on Tuesday  November. The alarm was raised when her daughter took a turn in nursery, and soon went into a daze and all but stopped breathing.The -year-old said the incredible paramedics helped the family come back around from what was described a “traumatic” experience for them, Plymouth Live reports. Charlotte and Ameliaaposs experience comes as the NHS is under intense pressure because of ambulance wait times, due to handover delays at hospitals. Ameliaaposs experience comes as a diabetic man, , was forced to wait nearly  hours for ambulance after fall in his kitchen in Staffordshire last Monday.Cyril Pepper was left with severe back pain and damage to his arm after banging his head falling at his home. Cyrilaposs situation is sadly not unique, but the paramedics were able to get to Charlotteaposs daughter because they were not far away when she called. She was suffering from anaphylaxis, a severe and potentially le threatening allergic reaction that can happen in a matter of seconds or hours when exposed to something the sufferer is allergic to. In Ameliaaposs case she is allergic to milk, butter cheese and cream. Amelia went into her first anaphylactic shock when she was just eighteen months old, where Charlotte had to use an EpiPen to save her le. Charlotte said other times she has come into contact with something she is allergic to, she has come up in a rash. Charlotte received a phone call from her nursery to tell her that Amelia was not herself, so they collected her and took her home. Charlotte told PlymouthLive: “I had a phone call from her nursery saying that she went really quiet, a bit dazed and glazy eyed and lucky enough my mum was home to pick her up. “She was then trying to talk to me but her breathing was quite shallow and disrupted, so I tried to talk to her and then realised somethingaposs not right here, so I ran downstairs to grab her EpiPen.“I jabbed her with the pen then called  and I know the NHS is under so much pressure, which is such a shame, but luckily enough within three and a half minutes they were with us and got her into recovery position.” Charlotte said it was her second time using an EpiPen on Tuesday and she did not realise fully what was going on, and did not know all of the signs to look out for with her daughter, so when she did use it, she said it was too late. She said that minutes before the paramedics arrived she watched her daughter all but stop breathing and go a grey colour that was an emotional experience. Not long after the paramedics arrived to open her airways and give her another shot of an EpiPen to help ease off Ameliaaposs anaphylactic shock. Charlotte said: “They were just absolutely fantastic, they stayed here and made sure she was stable, watched her from the EpiPen being used. They reassured us and thanked me really for doing everything that I could have in that situation. “They were just amazing. When they left they, left us feeling quite confident knowing what we had to do and what to look out for.” Although Charlotte said she felt awful for calling the paramedics after seeing the pressure on the NHS in the media, they reassured her to always call them whenever she uses a EpiPen on her daughter. title: peter sutcliffe ian brady nilsen
story: I work with Peter Sutclfe, Ian Brady and Dennis Nilsen... not all killers are evilForensic psychologist Kerry Daynes, , doesnt believe that all infamous British killers are evil. Shes worked with some of the most famous killers in our country, such as Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutclfe, Moors Murderer Ian Brady and necrophile Dennis NilsenKerry Daynes has been a forensic psychologist for  yearsByKirsten JonesFeatures  Lestyle Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsWolfing down my chicken kebab supper, I look around the table and idly wonder what most folk would make of my fellow diners – a collection of ex-murderers, sex offenders and arsonists. But I’m not frightened. It’s  and part of my job is spending time in this “halfway house” in a busy northern city. Imy empty plate to Nigel, a shy man who’s washing up. Suddenly, I feel a blow to my stomach. Nigel has stabbed me with a in kebab skewer. He looks panicked, eyes flicking from side to side. I remain calm, staggering to the staff office while blood seeps through my white blouse. “Call an ambulance!” I gasp, slumping to the ground. I’ve been a forensic psychologist for  years, working with some of the most famous killers in our country, such as Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutclfe, Moors Murderer Ian Brady and necrophile Dennis Nilsen.  I use science and psychology to try and analyse people who commit crimes – from shoplting to shocking murders – and determinethey’re safe to be released from prison.I’ve always had a fascination with the macabre. As a child I read horror stories about killer grannies and watched Doctor Who from behind the sofa – monsters were about the only things that scared me. This career was my calling.I remember the first time I walked into a prison. It was Strangeways – now called HMP Manchester. I was a naive -year-old, keen to learn about crime psychology. It sounds cheesy, but I wanted to create a world with fewer victims in it. On my tour, the inmates started catcalling, “There’s some p***y on the wing!” The prison officer rolled his eyes at my confusion. He knew I’d be eaten alive. Two years later, in , I volunteered as a psychology assistant at Wakefield prison, nicknamed Monster Mansion by insiders. It’s full of sex offenders and murderers I’d only seen in the newspapers. I was feet away from parent killer Jeremy Bamber, Colin “Gay Slayer” Ireland and child murderer Terence McCready. It was utterly surreal yet I was so excited. This was long before the #MeToo movement and the male prison officers gave me a hard time. One day I interviewed a man who raped, strangled and murdered a woman. While we talked in the cell, the officers locked me in for a laugh.  When I tugged at the door, it wouldn’t budge. Then it hit me… I was stuck in a room with a killer. I tried not to look frightened but I’m a redhead, I must have flushed like a tomato. He looked at me with a creepy smile. I was intimidated and genuinely scared – and he loved it. He said to me, “You’ve got a pretty neck, you know. It looks a lot like my victim’s.” I was only locked in for  minutes, but it felt like forever. Another inmate called out, “Are you alright in there, Miss ” adding, “I hope you’re treating her well.” That was his way of telling the inmate I was locked in with, “I’ll deal with youyou don’t.” I shook like a leaf that afternoon, but it didn’t put me off. Nowadays, I’m desensitised to a lot of things others would find completely paralysing. You’re probably used to seeing grey-haired men commenting on crimes on TV, but most forensic psychologists are women. People still think I chop up dead bodies for a living – that’s not my job. Nor am I running around the country trampling over crime scenes in my high heels and single-handedly arresting serial killers, like they do in TV dramas. Not all of my clients are dangerous, either. In  I worked with a -year-old named Frank Ecclestone, who confessed to a gruesome assault with a baseball bat. It was a messy case and the victim had almost died. Frank was regarded in the community as “a bit strange”. When I interviewed him, he was wearing a T-shirt featuring John Wayne Gacy – the “Killer Clown” who murdered at least  young men and boys. Not only did this quiet young man confess to the assault, he also blurted out that he was a serial killer and began headbutting the hospital wall.Afterwards, we were intercepted by another patient who had slit her wrist. My arm turned red as I gripped her wound to stem the flow. Meanwhile, Frank had gone a terrible shade of green. I knew he wasn’t a serial killer. Nor hadhe assaulted the victim. He was clearly scared of blood.Frank had given a  confession. It turned out that he had been raped by his stepmother as a child, and his little sister Holly was actually his daughter. His father threatened him and Frank confessed, “If I could say I was a killer he [Dad] would be scared to fight me.” To Frank, killers were powerful people who commanded attention and respect. Indeed, serial killers have become almost like pop-culture celebrities. I’ve been contacted by women who have US killer Ted Bundy’s teeth marks tattooed on their bodies – they think he was sexy! One day I was sitting on the sofa at home watching telly when the phone rang. I put the phone to my ear and heard a faint Scottish burr: “Hello Kerry, this is Dennis Nilsen.”  I thought it was a wind-up, but it really was him. Dennis talked to me in graphic detail about his offences, keeping his fantasy alive. He spoke bitterly about his childhood in a Scottish fishing village, where he was bullied and was dishonest about his sexuality. He blamed a great deal of his dissatisfaction in le on his mother. Over four years he phoned me  more times. They were long, rambling telephone calls. Dennis loved to talk about himself and I wanted to understand his distorted version of the events that occurred at Melrose Avenue and Cranley Gardens in London. He’d revel in the TV shows about him. Receiving telephone calls and text messages from offenders and victims is common – you wouldn’t believe how many I’ve had. So Dennis’s chats weren’t that surprising. I now have Callon my phone, because I never know who’s going to ring me. A few years ago, I really felt fear. I was on TV talking about Jeremy Bamber. Jeremy doesn’t like me – he claims I wrote  stories about him and that I was never a qualied psychologist, which is nonsense. Anyway, someone who was watching became my stalker. This man set up websites in my name, claiming to be a fan of mine – I’m a forensic psychologist, not Britney Spears! He wanted photographs and information about me and when I politely declined, he got angry and wrote awful things about me. He said I was the criminal, he knew the size of my breasts and described what I was wearing each day. He was physically watching me and I was terried. One day I found the words “Jill Dando” written on my fence and, behind it, the leless body of my cat. I was devastated by the death of my poor pet.  I took the man to court myself and paid thousands to have the awful websites removed. Only then was he arrested and given a harassment warning. It was  and I felt more afraid at home alone than I ever did in a prison full of killers. I’m a single woman, so there’s no man to worry about me. And I didn’t tell my parents or sister about being stabbed with that kebab skewer – I didn’t want them to fret. But now, after  years in the business, I could tell my family anything and they’d take it in their stride.It’s only when I talk about my job that I realise how surreal it sounds, but after work I come home, do the washing up and watch Strictly like everyone .In the past I’ve spent a lot of time in therapy to stop me remembering crime scene photographs or the horrors that I’ve heard. But I’m not scared of anyone I’ve worked with – I find politicians far more frightening than murderers. I’ve met people who’ve done dreadful, unforgivable things, but I don’t believe they are evil. It’s my job to find those human drivers behind inhuman behaviour. Every person has a story. title: significant day history glorious reign
story: Signicant day in history of glorious reign as Queen misses Remembrance serviceFor now, we are told Her Majesty has been told to rest up at Windsor and will be up to doing light duties as she recovers, writes Royal Editor Russell MyersThe Queen missed the service due to a bad back Image: Getty ImagesopinionByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsAs the national anthem rang out, sung with fervour by the hundreds who gathered at the Cenotaph with military veterans and the Royal Family, it was impossible not to feel this year had a special signicance. Just  minutes before, royal aides had announced that the Queen had “with great regret” not been able to join the event due to a back strain. In a reign of almost  years it was only the seventh time she had not attended and just the first due to illness. Palace aides hurried to allay fears that Her Majesty’s condition was not more serious, but many will be worried, given the unwillingness of Buckingham Palace to keep the nation informed when the Queen was in hospital last month. For now, we are told she has been told to rest up at Windsor and will be up to doing light duties as she recovers. Anyone who has suffered a bad back will know how awfully debilitating it can be.  No one would be more upset by yesterday’s turn of events than the Queen. She had been determined to make the commemorations, especially after last year’s scaled down ceremony due to Covid, the centenary of the Royal British Legion and the passing this year of her husband Prince Philip, a decorated military man. But we must remember that the Queen is . Her doctors and her family will hope she takes the opportunity to recover properly before her Christmas schedule kicks off. title: tory minister nadhim zahawi pockets
story: Exclusive: Tory minister Nadhim Zahawi pockets fortune from second job at oil companyEXCLUSIVE: Zahawi banked £.million from an oil company, which included a final £, “settlement payment” after he first became a Government minister in Tory minister Nadhim Zahawi has been able to keep his total second job earnings hiddenByTom PettorNick SommerladInvestigations Editor:,  Nov | commentsTory minister Nadhim Zahawi banked £.million from an oil company while working as an MP, but he has been able to keep his total second job earnings hidden due to a Parliamentary loophole. Mr Zahawi’s total earnings from Gulf Keystone Petroleum included a final £, “settlement payment” after he first became a Government minister in . Mr Zahawi was co-chairman of the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Kurdistan in  when he landed the job with Gulf Keystone, which has an oil field in Kurdistan and which paid him more than £, an hour. His Gulf Keystone income was declared in his register of interests, but his total second job earnings are not known thanks to Parliamentary rules allowing him to advise companies through Zahawi  Zahawi Ltd, a consultancy he set up with his we. Mr Zahawi did not respond to a request for comment. But Sir Alistair Graham, a former Chairman of the Committee on Standards in Public Le, said: “This could be interpreted as a deliberate attempt to get around the rules so that he doesn’t have to admit the scale of his earnings in a consultant capacity.  “The important thing to stress is that MPs have their personal responsibility to ensure that they comply not only with the letter but the spirit of the code of conduct. “Constituents have a right to know how much time and money he is taking separate to his political work.” Alex Runswick, of Transparency International UK, said: “Any new controls on MPs’ second jobs need to focus on potential conflicts of ­interests, not just the hours worked or additional earnings. “Any company owned by an MP risks becoming a shell behind which the extent of the work and these conflicts remain hidden.” Our probe comes after the outcries over Owen Paterson’s lobbying, and Sir Geoffrey Cox’s taxpayer-funded rental home and £million-a-year legal work.  The Mirror’s investigation has revealed how Mr Zahawi made a fortune in the murky world of business and politics in Kurdistan. Within months of becoming an MP in , Mr Zahawi became the vice-chairman of the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Kurdistan, taking five free trips to the region from  to . The secretariat to the group was funded by Gulf Keystone, the operator of the Shaikan oil field in the ­Kurdistan region of Iraq. Mr Zahawi was a guest speaker at a conference sponsored by Gulf Keystone and a second oil firm, Afren, in the Kurdistan capital Erbil in November . The two firms soon had Zahawi  Zahawi Ltd on the payroll.  Mr Zahawi’s father Hareth Zahawi’s firm Iraqi Project and Building ­Development was already involved in construction projects in Kurdistan. One source told the Mirror IPBD also had a monthly contract with Afren. The Mirror has found an archived page from the IPBD website which stated it had a joint venture with Sirwan Barzani, the nephew of Masoud Barzani, who was President of Kurdistan from  to . Sirwan Barzani has been accused in US court documents of corruption at his Iraqi telecoms company, but denies the “baseless” claims. Nadhim Zahawi’s register of interests shows Zahawi  Zahawi Ltd advised IPBD from  to . It is not known how much the role paid and there is no suggestion Mr Zahawi or his father knew of any corruption. Zahawi  Zahawi Ltd was an adviser to Afren from  to , according to the register of members’ interests, but it is not known how much the role paid. Mr Zahawi quit Afren after the Serious Fraud Office began a bribery investigation, which led to two Afren executives being jailed for fraud and money laundering.  There is no suggestion Mr Zahawi was invloved in wrongdoing. When he stopped advising Afren in  he became Chief Strategy Officer at Gulf Keystone, initially earning £, and later £, for eight to  hours a month, which he declared. Just weeks after taking the appointment, the Kurdish oil ministry agreed to begin huge payments to Gulf Keystone as part of an existing oil deal. High Court papers reported by the Organised Crime and Corruption Reporting Project allege that Gulf Keystone secured the oil field, prior to Mr Zahawi’s involvement, through a corrupt deal with Kurdish politicians. The claims are denied.Mr Zahawi went on to receive almost £, in “bonus payments” from Gulf Keystone before he left in December . He was then paid an additional £, for “salary in lieu of notice” along with a £, “settlement payment”. This last payment was made in May , four months after he was appointed a junior minister at the Department for Education by then-Prime Minister Theresa May. Mr Zahawi founded Zahawi  Zahawi Limited with his we Lana in June , weeks after he became an MP. He quit as a director in  when he became a Government minister and transferred his % stake in the company to his we. Mr Zahawi’s grandfather was a senior Iraqi politician, but the family fled Saddam Hussein’s regime in the s. In , Mr Zahawi told the Commons his “family arrived on these shores with only £”. title: towie loving jihadi says never
story: Towie-loving jihadi says she never should have gone to Syria to join ISISTareena Shakil, , was jailed in the UK in  after taking her toddler son to Syria and joining the terror group - she now claims to be deradicalisedTareena Shakil is the first British ISIS ee to tell her story Image: STEPHEN FOOTEByMartin Fricker:,  Nov | commentsA TOWIE-loving mum who was the first British woman to be convicted of Islamic State membership claims to have been deradicalised. Tareena Shakil, , was jailed in the UK in  after taking her toddler son to Syria and joining the terror group. She was released two years later and now insists she no longer poses a threat to Britain. A judge said Shakil travelled to war-torn Syria “to produce the next generation of fighters”. She said: “It’s not something I’m happy about looking back.” The former school prefect claims she was deradicalised by the East London-based Active Change Foundation.She was filmed during the process for an ITV programme last night and said she wishes she could turn back the clock. Shakil secretly went to Raqqa after telling her family she was going on a short break. She said: “If I could go back I would have come back, I would have gone to Turkey on holiday. “Being aware of horric things happening in that place and still deciding to run away, not just on your own, with your child… I understand that is hard for people to understand. “And to just say you didn’t pay that much attention to it, but that’s what it was, I just... I didn’t. It’s easy for everybody to say, ‘She did this, she did that.’ “But you really have no idea what I was living through.”  Shakil, from Burton-on-Trent, Staffs, was jailed for six years at Birmingham crown court. The Spice Girls fan was also found guilty of encouraging terrorism on social media. Asked what she thinks about ISIS bride Shamima Begum, who has lost her British citizenship and is in a Syrian camp, Shakil said: “I can’t sit here and say, ‘No, don’t bring them back’. “Because that makes me a hypocrite because I’ve been in a very similar situation. “It’s not the same because I escaped. It’s not easy to escape. It takes strength, it takes courage, it’s le and death.”The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. story: Two bank workers caught in £k customer account fraud after office desk searchedThe fraud was spotted by the bank and referred to the Dedicated Card and Payment Crime Unit , a specialist police unit sponsored by the banking and finance industryPolice searched the one of mens desks at workImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByJames RodgerRegional Content EditorGraeme Murray:,  Nov , a specialist police unit sponsored by the banking and finance industry" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Bank-workers-caught-in-£k-fraud-after-office-desk-searched.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top", a specialist police unit sponsored by the banking and finance industry" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Bank-workers-caught-in-£k-fraud-after-office-desk-searched.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top", a specialist police unit sponsored by the banking and finance industry" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _Bank-workers-caught-in-£k-fraud-after-office-desk-searched.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsTwo bank workers were caught in a £, fraud after their office desks were searched. Gerald Francis Sarpong and Mohammed Mehboob Uddin, racked up £, in fraud across  months back in . In July of that year, Sarapong from Essex, was arrested when officers searched his work desk in Birmingham where and seized digital devices. They found messages on his mobile phone sent to Uddin with customer account details. Police arrested Uddin at his home in Bethnal Green, London, on July ,  after obtaining a search warrant and seizing his digital devices and documents. The fraud was spotted by the bank and referred to the Dedicated Card and Payment Crime Unit , a specialist police unit sponsored by the banking and finance industry that investigates the criminals responsible for fraud. Sarpong and Uddin pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud and were sentenced on November  at London Crown Court to five years and  months and six years and eight months imprisonment respectively. All victims had funds fully refunded by their bank. The men had used mobile phones to send each other customer account details. Police say the men thought they could get away with the fraudulent activity in a work place where workers are trusted by their employerBen Hobbs, Detective Sergeant of the DCPCU, told BirminghamLive : Sarpong and Uddin acted with impunity, thinking they could get away with committing over £, of fraud.This case shows that anyone who is caught abusing the trust placed in them by their employer will be punished. story: Man who spent  years in jail for murder he didnt commit is finally freedDonate Sharpe was finally freed after spending  years in prison for a crime he did not commit even after a key witness had "entirely made up" her testimonyDontae Sharpe was ly imprisoned for murder and spent years fighting for his freedomByBethan EdwardsKieren Williams:,  Nov | commentsA man who spent  years in jail for a murder he did not commit after a key witness lied has been finally freed. Dontae Sharpe was granted a full pardon by North Caroline Governor Roy Copper, on Friday after decades fighting for his freedom.Sharpe, an African American, was just -years-old when he was sentenced in  for murdering George Radclfe, , during a drug deal.He was convicted based on the evidence given by Charlene Johnson, who was then -year-old and claimed to have seen Sharpe kill Radclfe and described it in detail. However, Johnson recanted her testimony two weeks later and after decades of trying to get his sentence overturned, two evidential hearings in  destroyed the case against Sharpe.  Not only had Johnson withdraw her initial testimony,tried again she would testy that she was not present at the time of the shooting and that her trial testimony was entirely made up based on what she saw on television and what investigators told her. In addition to that, the medical examiner of the trial, Dr Mary Gilliand only learned of Johnsonaposs  testimony well after the trial was over andcalled to a retrial would testy that Johnsonaposs initial description of the shooting was medically and scientically impossible. Sharpe is now eligible to apply for compensation of up to ,after losing decades of his le, , for each year of wrongful imprisonment. Speaking about the case, Cooper said: I have carefully reviewed Dontae Sharpeaposs case and am granting him a Pardon of Innocence. Mr Sharpe and others who have been wrongly convicted deserve to have that injustice fully and publicly acknowledged. Throughout his sentence, Sharpe maintained his innocence and refused to take a lighter sentence in exchange for a guilty plea. After being declared innocent, Sharpe said: Iaposm still in a haze, kind of. When youaposre dealing with us human beings, it can go any way, yes and no. I didnapost know what to expect. I was believing for a pardon. My familyaposs name has been cleared. Itaposs a burden off of my shoulders and my familyaposs shoulders. Iaposve been in there and know there are guys that are innocent and know that our system is corrupt and needs to be changed.  This is far from the first time an African American has been convicted of a crime they did not commit. Ronnie Long, , was sentenced to  years in prison for rape and burglary in  but released after spending  years behind bars. He had always maintained his innocence too. story: My cousins mad I refused to adopt her four kids that I didnt know existedA woman took to Reddit to ask for advice after her cousin hit out at her for refusing to take care of her children but users praised her for having the childrens best interests at heart" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _GettyImages-.jpg" width"" ""  Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsWhen a member of the family is in trouble, itaposs only natural to do everything you can to try and help. But is there a line when it comes to whataposs acceptable for someone to ask you to do  One woman has revealed she was put in a dficult position after her cousin asked her to adopt her children.Unsure of what to do, she posted anonymously on Reddit, asking others for their advice.I, , grew up being pretty close to my cousin, also , she said. Then in high school, she got really into the drugs party thing and ended up dropping out in her senior year. She eventually had my nephew ‘Evan’, now . I babysat a lot for her — I was attending college locally, so I was around to help out. Long story short, the stuff I saw ended up with me calling CPS . They determined it wasnapost bad enough yet to remove Evan but did give her some kind of parenting plan. Not sure what, as she cut off everyone in the family at this point. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Fast-forward to now, I moved away for grad school, then came back to my hometown,” she said as she hadnapost been in contact with her cousin since she had left to pursue her education. She contacted me through an older email account,” she explained. She said that CPS had removed Evan and his siblings Connor, , and Gracie, , three years ago — I wasnapost even aware sheaposd had other kids. After being taken from their mum, the kids had been staying with a foster family. Now CPS was taking away her rights for not working her plan, and she had given my name to them as a relative who would adopt them, she continued, which is why her cousin reached out in the first place. She begged me to take them since I was the only family member who even had a possibility to , the poster revealed. Turns out the foster parents also have my cousinaposs youngest child Anna, , — which my cousin never mentioned!  I guess since was born later in the case, sheaposs not on the same timeline, and my cousin isnapost losing her rights to Anna yet.She arranged to see her cousinsapos kids and theirfoster parents in a local park to help her make her decision.After seeing them, she thought they all seemed happy and it was clear that the kids LOVE their foster family. She continued: The family had two older kids — Iaposd guess older teens — and I could see the bond between all of them. I decided not to try and take the kids, but the foster parents are allowing me to stay involved in their le as an aunt figure, she wrote. Evanstill remembers me vaguely, and was happy to see me. She didn’t want to take the kids from the foster home because she didn’t want the drama, she admitted. On top of not wanting to take them from the only home most of the kids remember, I also donapost want to deal with my cousin — sheaposs still using and is not someone I want in my le right now, she sadly admitted. But when she told her cousin her decision, she was furious.  She said the kids deserve to grow up with their family, and Iaposm doing a terrible thing by not adopting them. The woman asked Reddit users whether she was in the wrong for not wanting to adopt the children, but many people were on her side. One person said: Not the a**hole AT ALL!!!! The kids sound like they are in a good place, it sounds like they are happy and healthy and perhaps may even be adopted by them in the future. Bonus, you can stay part of their lives. Another wrote: [Original Poster]’s cousin is right that the kids deserve to grow up with family. But their ‘family’ is the foster parents that have been caring for them for the last three years. Sam Smith said that she booked the day off work to decorate the tree, which cost her £ and was supposed to tower over her - and came complete with a working train, moving model village, and a model of Santa climbing a ladder up the tree. But she neednapost have bothered, as what arrived looked nothing like the advert, and the nurse from Liverpool described it as more like a apostwig and two baublesapos that stood just six inches tall. Sam, , soon saw the funny side - saying that the tree came in a smaller package than her phone charger, and is smaller than her six-month-old Cockapoo, Ralph.She said: The tree that was advertised was lovely. It was supposed to be six feet tall with Father Christmas carrying a ladder and a working train. But we got a six-inch tree which was basically a twig with a couple of baubles, a bit of string and a Father Christmas with a deformed face. It looked like the paint had been chucked on. I ordered a charger for my phone that arrived the same day as the tree and the charger came in a bigger box than the tree. We were crying with laughter. It was so funny.  Sam and her mum, Karen, had ordered the tree from online shop Wulimer after seeing it had been reduced from £ to £. The Wulimer website, which appears to have dropped the price of the ft tree even further to £. while claiming they have aposlimited stockapos, bragged that it was handmade and aposuniqueapos. Sam shared a snap of her online shopping fail on social media and other users were quick to share how hilarious they found the incident. I think it was about £ or something.Sam said: I decorated it and posted a photo of it on Facebook and everyone was saying they couldnapost believe weaposd fallen for it.Weaposve put the decorations on and put it on the side for fun. Karen added: Everyone was laughing and telling us to get our money back but its not about the money, people will fall for it. Although Sam found the funny side and made use of the tiny tree by displaying it in her kitchen, she has requested a refund from the company but is yet to hear back. Sam said: We paid through PayPal so should be able to get my money back. About three days after weaposd ordered it, I sent a photo of it to my friend whoaposd ordered the same tree and theyaposd also received the tiny one so itaposs happened to a few people.
